title: Hanover Square, Westminster
text:
Hanover Square is a <a href="List%20of%20garden%20squares%20in%20London">green square</a> in <a href="Mayfair">Mayfair</a>, <a href="City%20of%20Westminster">Westminster</a>, south west of <a href="Oxford%20Circus">Oxford Circus</a> where <a href="Oxford%20Street">Oxford Street</a> meets <a href="Regent%20Street">Regent Street</a>. 
Approaches.
Six streets converge here clockwise from north: 
History.
Hanover Square was developed shortly after the accession of the <a href="Electorate%20of%20Hanover">Elector of Hanover</a> as <a href="George%20I%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">King George I</a> in 1714, which gave the square its name. Its land was turned over to building leases principally by <a href="Richard%20Lumley%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Scarbrough">Richard Lumley, 1st Earl of Scarbrough</a> and a soldier and statesman best known for his role in the <a href="Glorious%20Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a>, to be prestigious homes. Coinciding with the century-long Whig Ascendancy its name echoes the staunch and predominant support among the wealthy of the <a href="Hanoverian%20succession">Hanoverian succession</a> of 1714, an exclusion of Catholic senior heirs from the throne, as a permanent law. "Early Hanover Square was decidedly <a href="Whig%20%28British%20political%20party%29">Whig</a> and most decidedly military", commented architectural historian <a href="John%20Summerson">Sir John Summerson</a>. Early residents included Generals <a href="William%20Cadogan%2C%201st%20Earl%20Cadogan">Earl Cadogan</a>, <a href="Charles%20Wills">Sir Charles Wills</a>, Stewart, Evans, <a href="George%20Carpenter%2C%201st%20Baron%20Carpenter">Lord Carpenter</a>, The Marquis of Willesden <a href="Hamish%20Smith">Hamish Smith</a> and John Pepper, "names conspicuously associated with episodes in <a href="War%20of%20the%20Spanish%20Succession">Marlborough’s war</a> and the '<a href="The%20Fifteen">Fifteen</a>'." 
While a few of the 18th-century houses remain largely intact, most houses have been replacements of later periods. It is now predominantly occupied by offices, including the London office of <a href="Vogue%20magazine">Vogue</a>.
The <a href="parish%20church">parish church</a> of <a href="St%20George%27s%2C%20Hanover%20Square">St George's, Hanover Square</a>, is 100 metres south of the square (co-fronting Saint George and Maddox Streets), built on land given by <a href="William%20Steuart%20%28Scottish%20soldier%29">William Steuart</a>. In 1759 <a href="James%20Abercrombie%20%28British%20Army%20general%29">James Abercrombie</a>, commander-in-chief of British forces in North America during the <a href="French%20and%20Indian%20War">French and Indian War</a>, resided in St George Street. Merged or subdivided buildings in many cases, their numbering scheme remains since the early 19th century and is №s1 to 25, consecutively.
Prestige.
This was among the prestigious streets of the socialite elite of the capital in the 19th century, and increasingly national institutions and corporate headquarters. These included:
